Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: An Experimental Test of the Impacts of Transparency by Government

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project tests whether transparency by government leads to beneficial outcomes such as better performance by government, more engagement from citizens in public life, and improved trust in government. These kinds of outcomes are the reasons why so many countries, including the United States, have embraced transparency by government. Yet, there is not much direct evidence that transparency efforts by governments produce the noted results.

The project uses a randomized field experiment to test whether transparency by a government agency affects citizen support for government and improves the administration of public funds. Data on these outcomes is used to statistically test for the effects of government-led transparency at individual and community levels. Funding is for Phase 1 only of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Transparency is frequently considered a key reform in rooting out corruption and creating government accountability. Yet, fundamental propositions about how transparency by government leads to the accountable administration of the government have not been subject to rigorous testing. This is particularly concerning in places where institutions are poor, media is constrained, and non-governmental organizations are limited in number. The goal of our project was to test the impacts of administrative transparency in the context of developing democracy. Specifically, we test three main propositions: (1) that targeted and actionable governmental transparency would work to reduce corruption and improve governance because it places the public in a better position to hold poor-performing and corrupt officials accountable; (2) that transparency would mobilize the public because it would inform citizen beliefs about government performance and raise the ability of citizens to act together by creating common knowledge about what the government has done and who is responsible for poor outcomes; and, (3) that governmental transparency would change citizen attitudes about government because it would provide a credible signal that powerful officials have interests that are aligned with citizens in promoting accountability. For the portion of the initiative funded by NSF, our work has mainly focused on the first of these hypotheses — that when governments are more transparent about their operations, corruption will decrease and the outcomes of public projects will improve.

We studied this question using a randomized controlled trial with a partner government agency in Uganda, a developing democracy that has both significant problems with the performance of governments, but also a growing commitment to administrative transparency. We collaborated with management of a national park in Uganda to introduce transparency about a program that funds local development projects and test its impact. In particular, the Uganda Wildlife Authority provided information about government budgeting and an opportunity to provide feedback about the spending to some villages near a national park, but others did not receive the information or the opportunity to respond to the information. We measured whether transparency increased public participation in public meetings where development projects were selected and also whether transparency resulted in improved government oversight and delivery of the development projects by local officials.

Although our qualitative results suggest that when transparency exposed corruption some limited oversight resulted, surprisingly, we found transparency had no significant effect on almost any of our measurements on program implementation. Our findings are particularly significant for developing democracies and show, at least in this context, transparency advocates may have oversold the cleansing effects of transparency. A few rays of transparency shining light on government action do not disinfect the system and cure government corruption and mismanagement, though transparency can lay bare the nature of those problems. Once corruption and mismanagement are identified, it takes effective institutions and action from civil society to improve the outcomes of government programs. These results suggest that policies to create accountable institutions must be pursued together with legal reforms that mandate transparency, especially in the context of developing democracies. Linking legal reforms with other types of programs that empower the public is a promising direction. The results of this program informed national guidelines that determine how development projects near national parks are carried out and provided opportunities to an undergraduate researcher to co-author peer-reviewed research.
